target: Sometimes when we go to sleep, our brain makes up stories in our head. These stories are called dreams. But sometimes we don't remember them when we wake up because our brain forgets them too quickly. It's like when we play with toys and then forget about them the next day.

keep a dream journal by your bed.  every day you wake up write as much down as you can.  your brain will get better at it, until you can remember them in greater detail.  you can train your brain to do this.

There could be a few reasons why it seems like you do not dream, or why you forget your dreams easily. One reason might be that you are not getting enough sleep, and so your brain is not getting enough time to process information and create dreams. Another reason might be that you have a condition called sleep apnea, which means that you stop breathing for short periods of time during the night, which can disrupt your sleep and make it difficult to dream. Finally, some people simply don't remember their dreams because they don't pay attention to them. Dreams can be strange and hard to understand, so it's normal to forget them soon after waking up.

As time goes on, the demands of the internet will increase.  Pictures and videos will be higher resolution.  Sites will have a greater number of scripts.  The whole experience will be "richer".  Reddit itself will probably not change much, as it's an aggregation of content from elsewhere, but all those sites that are linked are going to need more bandwidth.

In order to cope with the increased demands, ISPs will be prompted to improve their service.  However... they don't NEED to.  Their audience needs their product and there isn't another option outside the big boys.  So what they'll likely do is increase the service *for those who pay for preferential treatment*.  That means links to big sites like the news outlets will keep up with the demands of the internet, while imgur and similar hosting sites will need to pony up the cash if they don't want to be left in the (relatively) dark ages of data transfer.

If Net Neutrality goes away, it means that some websites might have to pay more money to be seen by lots of people. This could make it harder for websites like Reddit to show cool stuff from other websites because they might not have enough money to pay for it.

If net neutrality goes away, it would mean that internet service providers could charge different prices for different websites. That means that a website like Reddit, which uses content from other websites, could be charged more money by the internet service provider. This could make it harder for people to access Reddit, and it might even make the website go away.

Net neutrality is a rule that says all websites on the internet should be treated the same. Without net neutrality, companies like Reddit could charge more for faster access to their content. This would mean that people who can't afford to pay would have a harder time accessing the information they need.

How to play Warhammer 40k, The tabletop game

To play Warhammer 40k, you will need a few things. First, you will need miniatures of the Warhammer 40k universe. These can be bought pre-painted, or you can paint them yourself. You will also need a playing surface, dice, and some sort of measuring device (either a ruler or a tape measure). Finally, you will need the Warhammer 40k rulebook.

Set up your playing surface. This can be a table, the floor, or even a large piece of cardboard. Place your miniatures on the playing surface. Once all players have their miniatures ready, you will need to agree on who will be the "attacker" and who will be the "defender."

The attacker will take the first turn, and the defender will take the second turn. Players will alternate taking turns until one player either runs out of miniatures, or concedes the game.

On a player's turn, they will roll dice to see how many "actions" they can take. These actions include moving their miniatures around the playing surface and attacking their opponent's miniatures. Attacking is done by rolling dice and comparing the results to the defending player's dice roll. If the attacker's roll is higher, then the defending player's miniature is "killed" and removed from the playing surface. The game ends when one player either has no more miniatures, or concedes the game.

Warhammer 40k is a fun game that you play on a big table with little toy soldiers. You and your friends each have your own army of toy soldiers, and you take turns moving them around and trying to make the other person's soldiers go away. It's like playing pretend battles with your toys! You use special dice to see if your soldiers are successful at shooting or fighting in close combat. The person who makes the other person's soldiers all go away first wins!

Alright, here's how it goes:

Likely, once friendly hellos are over, each side will bring over boxes or cases full of little cardboard or plasticard bits of terrain. they will find a nearby battlefield - really, just a big flat modified table thing on which they'll fight - and likely, they'll take turns putting down pieces of terrain until they're sure that it will be a fun match.

Assuming it's a 1 on 1 fight, each side will bring an amount of little dudes and tanks appropriate to the fight they're having. They'll then put these little dudes and tanks on the table. How many guys start on the table, where they start on the table, and when they are allowed to come on is mainly decided by the deployment rules. there are couple of other things, but deployment rules are cricial to players deciding how they will play the game (for example: armies that really like shooting may prefer corner deployments because it dramatically increases the space between them and the other guy). There are also "missions" which determine whether the players win by killing the other guy's dudes, or holding ground, or whatever.

In the actual game, format is usually as follows:
1. player one moves all his guys
2. player one shoots
3. player one "assaults" (i.e. has his dudes break out bayonettes and apparantly try to stab the other guy's dudes to death in a complicated hand-to-hand combat. This tends to be very all-or-nothing, and sucess is often decided by your ability to (get into these/avoid these) as much or as little as your army needs it. You **cannot** shoot into assault, so you better hope you can block an assault or that your guys die quickly if your army isn't good enough to just win these outright.

then player 2 moves, player 2 shoots, player 2 assaults...

This continues until turn 5, at which point, depending on dice rolls, the game either ends, or gets drag out another turn. on turn 6, they roll again, and either the game ends or it goes to turn 7. Turn 7 is as far as games can go normally. 

Now, I'm just trying to give a picture of the general flow of a game, without talking about more complicated ideas like leadership, or mechanization, or why you shouldn't play necrons, lol.

When you stretch, you unconsciously perform something called a 'valsalva manoeuvre' against your epiglottis. This is when you kind of breath out but close your windpipe so that no air can get out. It turns out this has a number of effects, mostly on circulation. Your cardiac output decreases, causing your blood vessels to constrict and your heart to beat faster to bring output back up. This is why after you stretch you sometimes get a brief palpitation.

The main reason that you might want to perform a valsalva manoeuvre, is that stretching will automatically otherwise expel air in the lungs. Contracting the muscles around you chest squeezes you like a boa constrictor, and unless you put a lid on it, you'll lose the breath you took in.

So basically, I would say you block your airway to stop you from losing your breath, but you let it trickle out slowly possibly to prevent overtaxing your heart (doesn't make a big difference, but who knows whether it gave our ancestors an advantage). That trickling sounds like a weird stretch gurgle.

EDIT: Or, now that I think of it, it could just be that your unconscious valsalva manoeuvre isn't strong enough to contain the air being expelled by your mighty chest muscles. Who knows.
When you stretch, your muscles lengthen and pull on your skin. This can cause a weird gurgling noise to come from your stomach or throat.
When you stretch, your body makes weird gurgling noises because it's trying to get rid of the tension.
Sometimes when we stretch, the air inside our tummy and throat moves around and makes funny sounds, like a gurgle. It's completely normal and happens to lots of people!

When we exercise, our body moves and uses energy. Calories are like little pieces of energy that help our body move and do things. Fat is a type of food that can give us lots of energy, but if we eat too much of it, it can make us unhealthy. Our heart beats faster when we exercise because it needs to pump more blood and oxygen to our muscles so they can keep moving.

Your body uses sugar as its main form of energy. Your body gains energy from three main macronutrients: fats, carbohydrates, and proteins. These three can ultimately break down into sugars, or be stored and used for body mass.

Carbohydrates are categorized into digestible and indigestible carbs. The indigestible carbs are fibers (also categorized as a complex carb; but fibers from vegetables mostly). Digestible carbs are complex carbohydrates (bread, wheat, etc) that break down into simple sugars, or simple sugars (plain sugar, fruit sugar, etc) themselves.

Fats are categorized as saturated, unsaturated, or trans. Trans take longest to process. Unsaturated take shortest. Saturated is inbetween.

Proteins are either used for muscle building or stored in fat for later use.

Carbs are quick source of energy that fills up blood sugar levels. When you exercise, your body taps into blood sugars via glycolysis. When it runs out, you tap into fat reserves under ketosis. When you are at the point of starvation, you undergo catabolysis nd consume muscle tissue.

Increased heart rate does two things : exercises your heart, and increases your body's metabolism. Increased metabolism just means increased consumption of energy.

Weight loss is simple : Burn more calories than you eat. Exercising makes you gain strength, which allows you to burn calories faster as you get stronger. So a good exercise routine would involve strength training to gain some muscle weight to better lose fat weight.
You should eat enough so that you aren't undergoing catabolysis and so that you maintain muscle weight.
Good rule of thumb : reduce fats, count your carbs and proteins when you work out.

Edit: fixing semantics

Exercise burns calories. Calories are the energy that your body needs to do things like move around and breathe. When you burn more calories than you eat, you lose weight.

Fat is packed with calories. When you eat fat, it travels through your body and turns into energy. This is why you can lose weight by eating foods that have a lot of fat in them.

Your heart-rate goes up when you exercise. Exercise makes your heart work harder so that it can pump more blood throughout your body. This increases the number of calories that your body burns.

Exercise, calories, fat, and heart-rate all work together to keep our bodies healthy. Exercise helps to burn off excess calories, which can help to prevent weight gain. Fat is an important part of our diet, but too much can lead to health problems. Heart-rate is a measure of how hard our heart is working, and can be affected by both exercise and diet.

Well, some chickens might be a little sad when farmers take their eggs, but many chickens lay eggs every day and don't really care if the farmer takes them or not. The farmer needs to take the eggs so that people can eat them! It's just like when your mom or dad cooks you breakfast and uses eggs to make your favorite omelette. The eggs come from chickens and are very yummy!

On a normal day, my chickens don't even notice... they lay their eggs in the nest box and then go back out to the run and forget about them. But periodically one will get "broody", meaning her mothering instincts kick in and she wants to sit on some eggs until they hatch. When this happens she'll become much more protective. She'll stay in the nest box most of the day, and the other hens will slip eggs under her so she'll care for them. When I go to take those eggs, she'll puff her feathers up to look bigger. She might peck at me when I take them. But once I've scooped them out she forgets about them almost instantly and just waits for new eggs to appear. Her instinct seems to be about protecting the space, not counting eggs.

Once she's sat on them for a week or so, though, she will become aware of their numbers. If I were to slip another egg under her then, she might try to knock it out of the nest. And once they hatch, I wouldn't be able to slip any other chicks in with her, unless one of her eggs hadn't hatched -- if she sat on 8 eggs, she'll want to raise 8 or fewer chicks and will reject any extras.
Some chickens get sad when farmers take their eggs, but others don't because they like to have eggs. Some chickens lay a lot of eggs and some chickens only lay a few eggs.
Some chickens might get sad when farmers take their eggs.

The lack of direct sunlight results in dew, rain etc drying up the slowest on this side letting the moss grow.

This is called a "cel," short for celluloid. It's a clear sheet of plastic with the image drawn on it. The background is painted on a different cel.
In cartoons, when an object is going to move, the animators might use a different shade of blue or green to indicate that it is the object moving and not the background.

In cartoons, sometimes objects that are going to move look a little different from the background. This is so we can see them better and know they're going to move. It's like when you play hide-and-seek and someone's foot is sticking out from behind the couch - you can tell where they are because something looks different from the rest of the room.

In older, hand drawn cartoons, they stacked different layers of the scene to make the full image. For example, you would only draw the background and sky once, and then put another layer in front of it that had your moving characters. That way, you could animate the front layer without having to redraw the background every time. 

Parts of the background that would move in a scene would be shaded differently so that the animators could position the different layers effectively for the animation to line up properly.

is -4.25 and -4.75. What does that mean?

The first number (-4.25) is the amount of correction needed for nearsightedness and the second number (-4.75) is the amount of correction needed for astigmatism.

The first number on its own for each eye, sphere, is a general near-sighted (negative) or far-sightedness.

The second number can be blank, meaning you just have trouble focusing at certain distances.

Since you have a cylinder number, you have an astigmatism.  More like trying to focus light though a weirdly placed clear football than a clear marble.  So your total prescription needs more than one indicator to describe the shape.

The axis number is used to combine the previous two numbers, so your eyeglass lens+actual eye work together as if they were a single properly shaped eye.

The muscles around your eye can make his correction manually if it isn't too strong a prescription by making your eye the correct shape.  In general though, they get worse at doing so as you age, and get tired if you force that all the time.

You'd have trouble seeing far away objects even without the astigmatism, but yours is moderately strong.  From a practical standpoint, more astigmatism=more important to have someone well-trained help you pick, measure, and fit your glasses.  The lens alignment and position are more important than if you had only a -2.5 sphere measurement, for example.  So, yes, see a real professional.

When we walk on wet sand, the water gets pushed down and away from our feet. That means there is less water left on top of the sand where our feet touched it. So even though our feet are wet, they leave dry footprints behind!

When you step you compress the space between the sand particles. This forces the water that was occupying the spaces out. When you lift your foot, the sand remains more compact than it was before. Also water is cohesive. It likes to stick to itself (Think of a drop of water on a table. It's not going to spread to cover the table unless you give it reason to.). So the water remains where it was pushed away to, leaving the sand drier than that around it.

When you walk on wet sand, your feet push the water out of the way. The water squishes up around your feet and then falls back down into the spaces between the sand grains. Your feet don't get wet because they are pushing the water away.

Walking on wet sand leaves wet footprints because when you walk, the water gets squished out between your toes, and it pools up in between your toes. When you stand up, the water falls out of your toes and it leaves a dry footprint.

A decibel is a tenth of a Bel. Literally deci-Bel and is abbreviated dB.
  
A Bel is a unit of *relative* power. It is a ratio of the measured entity divided by a standard entity.  So it is a fraction.  If it is  & lt; 1, the measured entity is less than the standard, and so forth.  
  
Because of the large differences in numbers (a millionth or a million times), it is expressed as a power of 10.  For example if something is a million times as powerful than the standard, it is 6 Bels, or 60 deci-Bels.  
  
So if you have something smaller than the standard, the number is a negative power of 10.  Something a millionth of the standard would be -6 Bels, or -60 dB.  
  
So, in electronics, where we want to measure how much noise is on a line compared to how much signal, you might see something on the order of -80 dB.  
  
If you are measuring power, you will see -3 dB a lot, because it is half the power.  Log10(0.5) * 10 = approx -3.    
  
One thing dB is used for is measuring sound pressure.  We base our sound pressure measurements on the minimum level of human perception of basically a mosquito 3m away, if you haven't been to too many rock concerts.  However, acoustic power varies by the ratio of the *square* of the pressure measurements, basically doubling the dB.

We have money so that we can buy things that we need or want.

Money is a medium of exchange, used to avoid the problems of a barter system. Before money, if I had a chicken and I wanted some apples, I had to find some guy who wanted a chicken and had some apples. It's time consuming and restrictive. What if I only wanted two apples? Could someone take half a chicken? 

Money gets rid of these problems though. If I have a chicken and want some apples, I can sell my chicken to *anyone* who wants a chicken, take the money they give me, and then give that to anyone who has apples. It makes transactions much easier.
Money is a way to trade things we want, like candy or toys, for things we need, like food or shelter.

The answer to this question is complicated, but it essentially boils down to the fact that companies want to make money, and they believe that they can make more money by hiring men. This is because of the historical precedent set by previous generations of workers; men have typically been paid more than women for the same job. Therefore, companies believe that they can get away with paying women less, because they think that women will accept lower wages. Additionally, there are often fewer women than men who are qualified for certain jobs, so companies may feel like they have to pay men more in order to attract and retain the best employees.

Some people think that companies should just hire women because they are more likely to be good at the job, but others think that this is not always the case. Companies might not be able to find enough qualified women to work in the same position as men, or the salary that a woman would receive might not be as high as a man's.

Sometimes companies don't hire women because they think that men are better at the job, even if that's not true. And sometimes they pay women less because they think they can get away with it. But it's important to treat everyone fairly and pay them the same amount for doing the same job.

There's an oft cited statistic that women make 70% what men do or something like that, and people interpret it as meaning that women get paid much less for the same job. In fact that number is a comparison of average wages for all women vs. Average wages for all men. They don't get paid less for the same job, they just take lower paying jobs on average. Aside from the dearth of women in high level corporate positions, a lot of high paying professions like engineering and skilled trades are staffed mostly by men, which results in the overall disparity. 

But you can't really fire a guy and replace him with a woman with the same skills and experience and pay her significantly less.
Our organs are different colors because of the different jobs they do. For example, our lungs are pink because they help us breathe.
Our organs are different colors inside our bodies because they're made of different kinds of tissues. The tissue that makes up our heart is red, for example, because it's filled with blood vessels.

It is not as dramatic as anatomy charts picture it (sort of like how veins are not really blue), but the color is directly related to the constituent cells (and possibly the amount of blood). 

For example, bones are off-white because the exterior shell (cortical bone) is mineralized tissue and it works out that the minerals give it a white color. Meanwhile, the brain is the color it is because the neurons are grayish and the fatty insulation is whitish. Finally, muscle can actually vary in color depending on what type it is. Slow twitch has a lot of capillaries as well as mitochondria and myoglobin, giving it a nice deep red color. Fast twitch has the least mitochondria and myoglobin, making it a paler color. 

Many other examples of organs exist, but they certainly aren't as color coded as anatomy textbooks make them appear.

Our body has many parts that help us do different things, like our heart pumps blood and our stomach helps us digest food. These parts are called organs and they come in different colors because they are made up of different kinds of cells and tissues that look different under a microscope. Just like how apples can be red or green, our organs can be different colors inside our bodies.

So for water to turn from liquid to gas it needs to be at a certain temperature (usually 100C) and then it needs to absorb enough energy to transition from liquid to gas, this is called Latent Engergy of Vaporization. This is why water "boils", because the pot of water may be at 100C but as some of the water absorbs enough energy to turn to gas it bubbles up through the rest of the water. The amount of energy for water at 100C to turn from liquid to gas is about 100 time more energy than to heat the water from room temperature to 100C. This is why only small parts of the water turn into gas at a time.

You can "flash boil" water, where it would all vaporize at once. To do this you would have to heat the water under enough pressure to raise the boiling point high enough that you could get enough energy into the water that once the pressure is released and the boiling point drops it all instantly boils. Though this would be extremely dangerous, because that would essentially be a bomb.

A better example is "flash freezing". Where water is super-cooled then with a single tap it all turns to ice in a second. Look up videos of that.

Water doesn't vaporize at the same time because it has a high boiling point. Boiling water can get hot enough to cause steam to escape, but the water still has a high boiling point so it doesn't vaporize completely.

When you put water in a bucket and heat it up, the water gets really hot and starts to bubble. The bubbles are called steam and they're made up of tiny drops of water that have turned into gas because they've gotten so hot. But even though some of the water has turned into steam, not all of it has. This is because the heat from the stove or fire is only heating up the parts of the water closest to it. So while some of the water is turning into steam, other parts are still staying cold and liquid.

The water doesn't vaporize at the same time because the molecules in the water need to gain enough energy to turn into gas. When you heat up the water, the molecules start to move around faster and bump into each other more. Eventually, some of the molecules will have enough energy to turn into gas, but not all of them.

Metabolism is how your body converts food into energy. There are three main ways to store this energy:

Inside muscle cells: when you see a bear, he isn't going to give you a 5 minute stretch and 10 minute walking warm up, you gotta run right now. This is only used in emergencies and is incredibly inefficient.

Inside the liver: this is your generic energy store, takes a while to get into action, but is very efficient.

Inside fat cells: this is a super efficient long term storage that is used very slowly.

When you eat food, the energy is allocated in roughly this order: your emergency muscle storage is filled up first, then your liver storage, then your fat cells, then if you have extra, your fat cells will duplicate.

If you are thinking about diets and losing fat, certain foods (specifically sugar), can very quickly fill up your muscle and liver stores, and also create a situation where there is too much glucose (energy) in your bloodstream. Your muscle cells will reduce their ability to take in glucose to protect themselves, which will make nearly all of your energy enter your fat cells, filling and duplicating them (making more fat). Too much of this leads to fat gain, and possibly diabetes. To reverse this process you have to trick your body into using your emergency muscle stores which will make new energy go to muscles and the liver, instead of straight to fat.

Some ways to do this are:

* Running for your life from a bear.

* Doing high intensity weights

* Sprinting

When you eat, your body breaks down food into molecules that it can use to produce energy. These energy molecules are called calories. Your body then stores these calories as fat, muscle, or bones. When you need energy, your body converts these stored calories into ATP (adenosine triphosphate). ATP is the molecule that your muscles use to do work.

Seeing the sensory input in both the short term and long term memory confuses the brain into thinking that it has experienced the event in the past and at the current time creating the feeling that you have experienced before.

Deja Vu is a feeling that you have experienced something before, even if you haven't. It's normal to experience it occasionally, but some people experience it more often than others. Different language groups make different sounds because they have different words for the same thing. For example, in English we say "caw" to make a sound like a rooster, but in Spanish we say "cuerno" because they have a word for "rooster" that is different.

Because how you hear something is heavily influenced by the language you live in. So the onomatopoeia you choose to represent that sound will be different in different languages. 

For example many native speakers of Asian languages have a massive issue telling an English "R" and "L" sound apart. Many more non-English speakers have trouble telling "C", "S", "Z" and "X" sounds apart (and some native English speakers too). Etc. 

You also have the fact that different letters and letter combinations make different sounds in different languages so while they onomatopoeia may be identical when spoken between two languages they will be spelled completely different.

Different people from different parts of the world make different sounds to describe things, like animals or machines. This is because they use different words and different sounds in their language. If there was a fire in the space house, the astronauts would be in big trouble because they can't run away like on Earth. To stop this from happening, they have special rules to follow and things like smoke detectors, fire extinguishers, and good ventilation that help keep them safe. They also practice what to do in case of a fire so they know how to stay safe.

If a fire were to break out on a spacecraft in orbit, astronauts would fight the flames in slightly different ways than they would on Earth. Fires in space are not the same as fires on Earth, but the best way to fight any fire is to keep it from starting.

As hot gasses from a flame rise, they create air currents that bring fresh air to the fire. This buoyancy is what makes a flame long and pointed here on Earth. In low gravity situations, there is no buoyancy from flames.Convection, the movement of air, is an important way that heat is transferred to other spaces. Without air, fires don't spread as rapidly. Ventilation fans on the Space Station replace natural convection and can supply the air a fire needs to burn. Under these circumstances, the fire can spread in any direction, rather than just upward.

The flame's unusual shape creates different amounts of soot, smoke or harmful gases. "Combustion in microgravity is a very difficult problem, and there are a lot of engineers and scientists working to understand it better," said Gary A. Ruff, aerospace engineer at Glenn Research Center's Microgravity Combustion Science Branch in Cleveland, Ohio.

All materials going up into space are tested for flammability on Earth in a special test chamber and ignited with a hot wire. Some items are so important to a mission's success that they're permitted to travel to space despite being flammable.

Detecting a fire in space is also different than on Earth. Here, smoke detectors are installed on the ceiling or upper section of a wall because that's the direction in which smoke travels. In space, smoke doesn't rise, so detectors on International Space Station are placed within the ventilation system.
While the ISS hasn't experienced a fire, a significant blaze did take place in 1997 on the Russian Space Station Mir. The fire came from an oxygen generator, where the oxygen supplied a ready source of fuel. Tests showed that the generator had to run out of oxygen for the fire to burn out. If a fire were to occur on the ISS, the astronauts would become firemen and follow a three-step response system.

First, they would turn off the ventilation system to slow the spread of fire. Next they would shut off power to the effected unit. Finally astronauts would use fire extinguishers to put out the flames.

Ruff says that while safeguards have been in place to prevent a fire from occurring on the Space Station, it's comforting to know that astronauts could respond to an emergency because they've prepared for any eventuality.

The International Space Station (ISS) is a place where astronauts live and work. It's in space, so if there was a fire on the ISS, it would be really hard to put out. The ISS is kept cool by a series of fans and radiators. If something were to catch on fire, the fans would start to spin faster and the radiators would heat up, which would put out the fire.

If there was a fire on the International Space Station, it would be very dangerous. The fire would spread quickly in the microgravity environment and could damage the station. The astronauts would have to use fire extinguishers to put out the fire.

If you approach this problem from a clean slate this can be answered rather simply. Lets presume you live to be 80 years old and we start this at the age of 20.

That is sixty years of life you gotta cover.

Short answer would be around 1,000,000 dollars if you live in the USA
Simply by living off the interest of this amount sitting in a bank would allow you to afford a very meager lifestyle, and towards the end of your life you could cash it in and spend the rest of it. Invested properly this could get you from 10,000 a year to 50,000 (the latter involving dividends and the prior sticking it into a savings account)

You have no assets, no car, no home, nothing. Starting here we need to understand what you want out of life. To simply survive, you only need around what food costs you a year, but then you'll be homeless- and probably won't make it to 80.

To have a property- depends greatly on where you live, but you need to pay an upkeep to keep your property (Taxes, fixing problems, replacing broken things) so we can take a stab at this- or you can go the route of renting which will be "Cheaper" but you will never be able to get the money back, where by owning a property eventually you pay it off and can resell it if you desire.

The reason people like to own a property is because as long as the value remains steady it essentially costs you "Nothing" outside of taxes/upkeep. If you live in it for 20 years and sell it for what you bought it for, you just lived in a house for "Free" 

We will call the property 150,000 + 200,000 in costs over your life if you don't sell it and live there all 60 years. This is a tiny house for one person. If you live in NY, I'm sorry but the 200,000 just turned into 600,000 but lets just pray you don't.

Cost of living, in the USA you need a car unless you live in a city- but lets pray you don't because cities are stupid expensive. Car lasts 10 years (rough estimate) costs 20,000. 20,000 x 6 = 120,000

Upkeep on car + Gas + Costs of living = 10,000 a year as long as you don't travel much/keep the car in good condition/don't eat out every day

TOTAL IT OUT: 

* Small cheap home/costs of renting for 60 years: 350,000 $ (If you buy, you can get a lot of this back when you decide to sell and move which makes this an interesting category as the house can essentially cost you nothing, and just act as a bank account you can't touch until you move.)

* Costs of cars at a 10 year life span: 120,000 $

* Costs of living/utilities/insurance over 60 years: 600,000 $

* Extra stuff/things I've missed: 100,000 $

This is not counting the money you will make off of interest, and state by state the taxes will be different so the costs of living could fluctuate dramatically depending.

If you took this as a magical lump some in a savings account and somehow avoided getting the shit taxed out of it you could live off the interest and be extremely poor- or invest it and live well enough off of dividends. This is a difficult question to answer due to the fact that currency- especially the dollar, might not hold over the next 60 years. I also don't know how "rich" you want to live.

The long and short of it though: 1.1 million $ to live as "Lower-middle class" and taking it as a given that it is simply just you and not a family

React properly to reviews from your customers. In your responses, you can highlight your business' policies and customer service.

Input: Another repeat visit and no disappointment from us. Great place for breakfast or brunch - and you won't need to eat again for awhile. The restaurant is close to the Tenderloin so be aware of your surroundings.
We enjoyed the Succotash Omelet (at least my wife enjoyed it), the Pulled Pork Benedict and the Hangtown Fry. Portions are large and pricing is fair. I wish we could have managed a Beignet Flight!
Definitely a spot to seek out. It can be crowed at times so be patient. Well worth any wait.

You are given some reviews for a movie. Each video might have mentioned some negative or positive points about the movie. Read them carefully and extract the positive and negative points mentioned in all of the reviews. Then, make a list of these points and summarize them as positive points and negative points.

Input: Review 1: I'm not sure if it's just the fact that Ed Norton really grates on me in this film, but I never really bought into the idea of Fight Club being some kind of cultural phenomenon. Yes it's an innovative story, told via a strong script, engaging characters and intense cinematography. But is it really worthy of such high praise? Personally, I find it starts to fall apart halfway through and actually becomes quite tedious towards the end. Everything just becomes a little bit childish and contrived as the story loses touch with its base elements and the rage against the machine vibe takes over. I have huge respect for the way this film was made but, much like The Matrix, I feel like people attach way more importance to this movie than it deserves.
Review 2: The film tells the story of men who cannot adapt to the social order in today's world, under the leadership of Tyler Durden, to discover their natural instinct, masculinity, and to escape from their unhappy lives.
Review 3: Despite a good theme, great acting and important messages that this movie convey in an unorthodox way, I think it fails to connect the audience with the storyline and leaves him in a world of confusion. Although, majority of reviews find this movie entertaining and interesting, yet I would choose to be a minority that believes that this movie is extremely overrated.
Review 4: Is creating chaos, explosions and membership in a militant sect the way to get rid of material shackles ?! The visual effects are fascinating and the story is compelling until the second half. Unfortunately, it doesn't end well.

A job description is a document that clearly states the requirements, duties, responsibilities, and skills required to perform a specific role. You need to write a job description based on the given information. You should describe responsibilities and duties in your job description in a logical order. Remember that potential employees often get their first impression of your company from your job description. So, the job description should convey the attractiveness of your company.

Input: Company: [Company name]
Job: Software Engineer
Job Responsibilities:
Receive and perform code reviews with other engineers.
Write unit, integration, and end-to-end tests to verify functionality using automated testing frameworks such as Pytest.
Work collaboratively with fellow software engineers to build features requested by business stakeholders.
Participate in Agile teams to develop, test, and debug complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark.
Diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects.
Skills and experience that will lead to success:
Experience with a modern software programming language. We use Python, and Pyspark extensively.
Experience with cloud systems like AWS or Azure
Experience writing SQL queries 
Strong written and verbal communication skills
Eagerness to work in a highly-collaborative environment
Some visualization experience such as Tableau or PowerBI is helpful

To start toning your abs by hitting up the lower abdominal muscles, Riggins suggests 30 seconds of leg raises. Here's how: Turn on your back with legs straight and your feet and ankles together. Raise your legs up and down in a vertical position from your body, while keeping your belly button. Slowly bring legs back down, but if that is too difficult, tuck your knees. (And be careful not to strain your lower back!)
Lie down on your back with feet flat on the ground. Raise your legs up so that your thighs and torso are in line with each other, and hold for two seconds. Slowly lower your legs back to the ground.

Instructions for Leg Raises:

1. Lie flat on your back on an exercise mat or comfortable surface.
2. Place your arms by your sides, with your palms facing down.
3. Slowly lift both legs off the ground, keeping them straight and together.
4. Continue lifting until they are perpendicular to the floor or until you feel a stretch in your abdominal muscles.
5. Hold this position for a few seconds.
6. Slowly lower your legs back down to the starting position.
7. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Note: It is important to keep your core engaged and avoid arching your back during this exercise.

Here's a quick and efficient office workout routine:

Breaking Bad is a television series about Walter White, a chemistry teacher who turns to cooking methamphetamines after he is diagnosed with cancer. He partners with former student Jesse Pinkman and the two of them cook crystal meth in an RV. The series chronicles their struggles to keep their operation going while avoiding the dangers that come with the illegal drug trade.

A high school chemistry teacher, Walter White, is diagnosed with lung cancer and given only a few months to live. With his family's encouragement, he decides to turn his life around by becoming a drug kingpin in order to provide for them.

Breaking Bad is a critically acclaimed TV drama series that follows Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher who turns to cooking and selling methamphetamine after being diagnosed with cancer. As he descends into the criminal underworld, he becomes increasingly ruthless and dangerous, forming an unlikely partnership with former student, Jesse Pinkman. The series explores themes of morality, family, and the consequences of one's actions.

Walter H. White is a chemistry genius, but works as a chemistry teacher in an Albequerque, New Mexico high school. His life drastically changes when he's diagnosed with stage III terminal lung cancer, and given a short amount of time left to live: a mere matter of months. To ensure his handicapped son and his pregnant wife have a financial future, Walt uses his chemistry background to create and sell the world's finest crystal methamphetamine. To sell his signature "blue meth," he teams up with Jesse Pinkman, a former student of his. The meth makes them very rich very quickly, but it attracts the attention of his DEA brother in law Hank. As Walt and Jesse's status in the drug world escalates, Walt becomes a dangerous criminal and Jesse becomes a hot-headed salesman. Hank is always hot on his tail, and it forces Walt to come up with new ways to cover his tracks.

One mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety is to focus on their breathing. Taking deep, slow breaths can help to calm the body and mind, and can also help to reduce stress levels. This exercise can be done anywhere, at any time, and only takes a few minutes to complete.

One effective mental exercise for managing anxiety is deep breathing. This exercise involves taking slow, deep breaths and focusing on the physical sensations of inhaling and exhaling. Here's how it works:

1. Find a quiet place where you can sit comfortably.

2. Close your eyes and take a few normal breaths to relax.

3. Inhale slowly and deeply through your nose, counting to four as you breathe in.

4. Hold your breath for a count of four.

5. Exhale slowly and completely through your mouth, counting to six as you breathe out.

6. Repeat this process for several minutes, focusing on

Submodalities
Giving a physical form to your anxiety can help your mind feel more in control of it. In this exercise, we will visualize what anxiety looks and feels like, and learn to reduce its intensity. Here are the questions that you need to answer:
1- Everyone feels anxiety differently. Where in your body do you feel it?
2- Now close your eyes and picture your anxiety. Try to give it color, shape, and temperature. What does it feel like?
3- Does it move, or is it in one place? If it moves, tell how it is moving.
4- Now for the good part, close your eyes and try changing this picture. Change how it moves. Slow it done shrink its size. Try to move it away from your body. Imagine it fading. Keep doing this until you feel like you can change how it feels. Changing which submodality helped you curb your anxiety? Was it its shape, size, or something else?
5- Do you feel better now?

Anxiety is a response to a perceived threat. It's an automatic, protective mechanism that helps us manage potential dangers.

Anxiety can be described as a feeling of apprehension, fear, or nervousness about something that is not yet happening. It can range from mild anxiety (a feeling of unease) to intense anxiety (a debilitating fear).

There are many different ways to manage anxiety. Some people use relaxation techniques to calm their nerves. Others use cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) to change their thoughts and behaviours around anxiety-inducing situations. Still others take medication to alleviate their symptoms.

Depending on the severity of the temperature change, travelers may want to adjust their travel plans in order to protect themselves from the elements. If the temperature change is only minor, then travelers may just need to dress warmer and bundle up when outside. If the temperature change is more severe, then travelers may want to consider rescheduling trips or checking hotel availability in case they experience extreme weather conditions.

If there is a sudden temperature change, it is important to adjust your travel plans accordingly. Here are some tips to help you do just that:

1. Check the weather forecast regularly: Keep an eye on the weather forecast and be prepared for any sudden temperature changes.

2. Dress appropriately: If the temperature drops suddenly, make sure you have warm clothing to keep yourself comfortable.

3. Adjust your itinerary: If you had planned outdoor activities, consider changing them to indoor ones. Alternatively, reschedule your trip for a time when the weather is more favorable.

4. Be aware of road conditions: Sudden temperature changes can lead to icy roads

-If the temperature drops suddenly, dress in layers so that you can easily add or remove clothing as needed.
-Carry a scarf or other type of warm headwear to protect against the cold.
-Be prepared for changes in road conditions, such as ice or snow, and plan your route accordingly.
-Allow extra time to reach your destination in case of delays due to weather conditions.

- Make sure that you have a good variety of options, and pack for the weather of your destination.
- Rapid temperature changes can have major impacts on your body. Make sure you are aware of your particular responses to temperature change and pack accordingly. 
- Make sure to pack ointments, creams and lotions to help keep your skin healthy while you are on the go. 
- With extreme heat, you may experience rash, fainting, headaches, and fatigue as well as nausea, sweating, and loss of coordination. Be particularly aware of heat exhaustion and heat stroke as these are serious medical conditions that can have serious consequences. In cold climates, be aware of frostbite and hypothermia, intense shivering, goosebumps, difficulty using your hands, and false sense of warmth can indicate a developing cold illness.

A road trip from San Diego to Los Angeles would be a great way to see the west coast. There are many stops along the way that would be great for seeing the sights and enjoying the activities. Los Angeles has many great museums and theaters that would be perfect for a day of exploring. There are also many great restaurants and shops to enjoy.

If you're looking for a scenic road trip, start in San Diego and head north. Along the way, make stops at Tijuana, Baja California, and Ensenada. In Los Angeles, take in Hollywood and the surrounding area. Alternatively, if you're looking for something more action-packed, head to the Joshua Tree National Park and spend time hiking and exploring the desert.

Begin near the city of San Diego and make the first stop in coastal La Jolla. This upscale little village is a great a place for an overnight, a day of sunbathing at La Jolla Shores Beach, or a cocktail with a view.
Just 20 minutes north, stop into beachy Encinitas to window shop the boutiques or sample fish tacos. Walk through the coastal meditation garden at the Self-Realization Fellowship or join surfers in the line-up at one of the fantastic local beaches here
Just up the coast is cute little San Juan Capistrano, home to one of California’s favorite missions. In spring, more than 6,000 swallows migrate here from Argentina! As you approach LA, don’t miss swank Laguna Hills. Home to the one-of-a-kind Pageant of the Masters art event, Laguna is brimming with artists and charm. It’s a great place for an overnight. Plus, Crystal Cove Beach in nearby Newport Beach is one of California’s finest!
After that, the choice is yours: Disney lovers should head directly to Disneyland in Anaheim to meet Mickey. To join the beautiful people and snap a photo of an iconic California scene, head to Santa Monica Pier and walk the boardwalk or ride the world’s only solar-powered Ferris wheel. A San Diego to LA road trip is the perfect way to enjoy all things Southern California.

The responsibilities of a security officer include protecting people and property, deterring crime, and enforcing laws and regulations. They may also be responsible for investigating crimes, responding to emergencies, and providing customer service.

A security officer maintains a safe environment on behalf of their employers. They ensure the staff, customers, visitors and business premises are secure. They patrol perimeters, use surveillance equipment to monitor activity and perform security checks required for visitors to the site.

The security officer is responsible for maintaining the safety and security of the building and its occupants. They may also be responsible for enforcing rules and regulations related to safety and security.

A security officer is responsible for maintaining a safe and secure environment by patrolling and monitoring premises, preventing theft, violence, and other illegal activities. Their duties may include:

1. Patrolling designated areas to ensure the safety and security of people and property.
2. Monitoring surveillance cameras and alarms to detect suspicious behavior or activity.
3. Checking identification and credentials of individuals entering the premises.
4. Responding to emergency situations such as fire, medical emergencies, or criminal activity.
5. Writing reports on incidents or suspicious behavior that occur during their shift.
6. Providing assistance to visitors and employees as needed.
7. Enforcing rules and regulations

Ingredients (for 12 cookies):
½ cup granulated sugar(100 g)
¾ cup brown sugar(165 g), packed
1 teaspoon salt
½ cup unsalted butter(115 g), melted
1 egg
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1 ¼ cups all-purpose flour(155 g)
½ teaspoon baking soda
4 oz milk or semi-sweet chocolate chunks(110 g)
4 oz dark chocolate chunk(110 g), or your preference
Preparation:
In a large bowl, whisk together the sugars, salt, and butter until a paste forms with no lumps.
Whisk in the egg and vanilla, beating until light ribbons fall off the whisk and remain for a short while before falling back into the mixture.
Sift in the flour and baking soda, then fold the mixture with a spatula (Be careful not to overmix, which would cause the gluten in the flour to toughen resulting in cakier cookies).
Fold in the chocolate chunks, then chill the dough for at least 30 minutes. For a more intense toffee-like flavor and deeper color, chill the dough overnight. The longer the dough rests, the more complex its flavor will be.
Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Scoop the dough with an ice-cream scoop onto a parchment paper-lined baking sheet, leaving at least 4 inches (10 cm) of space between cookies and 2 inches (5 cm) of space from the edges of the pan so that the cookies can spread evenly.
Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until the edges have started to barely brown.
Cool completely before serving.

- misfortune: The meanings of misfortune and adversity largely overlap; however, misfortune may apply to either the incident or conjunction of events that is the cause of an unhappy change of fortune or to the ensuing state of distress.
- mishap: The synonyms mishap and adversity are sometimes interchangeable, but mishap applies to an often trivial instance of bad luck.

The best time of year to visit Sydney, Australia is from September to November (spring) or from March to May (autumn). During these months, the weather is mild and pleasant with average temperatures ranging from 17°C to 25°C. The summer months (December to February) can be extremely hot and humid, with temperatures often exceeding 30°C. Additionally, this is the peak tourist season, which means crowds and higher prices for accommodations and attractions. But if you want to warm up with the masses from winter back home, the average daily temperatures in January can hit highs of 30°C/86°F and lows around 20°C/67°F.
